We s the face of the clock click to 2:45 AM. Then we hear the creak of floor boards and the lumbering footsteps of a man returning to bed. The space in the bed filled with the figure of the novelist JOSEPH CASTLEMAN, early 70's. He has the anxious, exhausted look of someone who doesn't have a prayer of sleeping. Joe is a handsome, aging Brooklyn boy turned literary giant. He has the bear and the bearing of a proper eminence grise but he is also unapologetic sensualist. He embraces all that life has to offer with a greedy, passionate vigor -- which, the criti tell us, is what makes his writing so rich. CRINKLE, CRINKLE, CRINKLE...Joe starts unwrapping a packa of Hostess Snowballs which he’s brought back to bed with Next to him, JOAN CASTLEMAN, his wife of 40 years, is on side, eyes shut, but awake, trying for sleep. She's five years his junior -- an elegant, educated, deeply self- possessed shiksa from the upper-east side who was bred to a muse and helpmate to some brilliant, charismatic man. CRINKLE, CRINKLE...
Joe. What’re you doing?
I'm hungry.

Birds are starting to chirp as dawn breaks on the Castlem home: a charming old Connecticut farmhouse, an appropriat residence for a famous novelist. We hear a PHONE start to ring inside.

Joe and Joan are fast asleep, each sprawled on their sepa sides of the bed. Dawn is just breaking. We hear birds start to chirp outside. The phone rings. On the second RING, Joe wakes up with a start and grabs t phone.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 4.

Hello. Am I speaking to Mr. Yoseph Castleman?
Yes. Yes you are.
This is Mr. Arvid Engdahl calling from the Nobel Foundation in Stockholm, Sweden. Joe presses his hand to his chest. Joan has woken up.
This is not a joke, I take it.
No, no, Mr. Castleman, I assure you. If you like I will give you the phone number here and you can call back to confirm.
Well thank you, that won't be necessary. Joe nods to Joan that this is it.
Oh my God...
Before you go on, can my wife Joan get on the extension?
Yes, of course, I'll wait. Joe madly gestures to Joan to GO.

Joan is now grabbing the phone on the desk. She's surroun by book shelves, which are mostly housing all the various editions and translations of Joe's prodigious work. She can hear Arvid and Joe chatting about the weather in Stockholm.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 5.

Yes it is.

Yes I am.
It is my great honor and pleasure to tell you Mr. Castleman, that you have been chosen to receive this year's Nobel Prize in literature. Joan lets out an involuntary gasp.
Well, thank you, thank you very much.

Mr. Castleman, we are so delighted to be giving you this prize. Your career has a truly remarkable span to it. Joan grows very still as she listens to Arvid's praise. ARVID ENGDAHL (ON PHONE) (CONT’D) Not only do you write with extraordinary intimacy, wit and depth, you have also challenged the novelistic form in ways that will affect generations of writers to come.
Well, I should be getting something for all the grey in my beard.

(laughing at the great man’s joke) Ah! Indeed, yes! And thank you for doing so on the world’s behalf! Joan's eyes are closed, her hand on her heart as she continues to absorb this news.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 6. ARVID ENGDAHL (ON PHONE) (CONT’D) Mrs. Castleman --
Yes.
You should know that your husband will be fending off the press today, so what I advise is that you monitor his calls, as it does get quite exhausting.
(a slight pause) Yes, I'll take good care of him.
Mr. Castleman, I'm sure you would like to make a few calls of your own, so I shall leave you to your celebration. We will contact you later with all the specifics. Again, many congratulations to you.

Good bye.
Good bye. STAY ON Joan. She's overwhelmed. We can hear Joe shouting for her.

Joan is coming back into the bedroom and she sees Joe standing on the bed.
What are you doing?
C'mon, get up here! Let’s jump!  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 7.

We'll break the bed.
Quit being so middle class. Get up here. Joan climbs up on the bed with Joe and stands unsteadily the mattress. Joe starts to bounce. Joan lets out a littl shriek. Joe takes her hands.
I'm going to fall.
No you aren't. He bounces a little more.
Joe, be careful.
Screw careful. Come on, jump! Joan starts bouncing with him, laughing, giddy.
(in a silly sing-song) I won the Nobel, I won the Nobel! La-la, la-la la la!
Joan stops bouncing.
What. Joan doesn’t say anything, just shakes her head.
Joanie. Come on. I’m just being silly.
I need to take a shower. We have a long day. Come down. Joan helps Joe down.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 8.
Joanie, I love you.
I know, Darling. Joan gives him a kiss and heads for the bathroom.

A celebration party. FRIENDS and FAMILY are gathered in t well-appointed living room artfully furnished with good r and limited-edition black & white art photos. They’ve all come up from Manhattan i their good suits to lavish Joe with pricey bottles of win His agent and editor are younger than Joe -- he’s outlive the last bunch. But his longtime publisher, HAL BOWER, 70 is still vital and a dapper dresser. He gives his star writer a bear hug and booms his congratulations. We see a motley collection of Joe’s longtime WRITER FRIEN bent over a table of catered food, consuming large amount Joe's food and liquor to make up for the fact that they didn't get the Nobel. Hello, Hal.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 9.
Hello there Joan! You’re looking lovely as always.
Thank you, Hal, that’s very sweet of you.
The New York Times is here. (to his publisher) Tell her.
They're giving your husband the cover of the Sunday magazine. They’re knocking out a story about Bill Clinton for him.
Oh my God.
Is this like an Avedon shot? With all the pores showing?
Every brilliant one of them, my friend.
Joanie, am I clean? Joan checks Joe’s beard for crumbs.
You're fine.
Nose hairs?
All good. Joe is trembling a bit, wired from adrenaline. He clutche Joan's arm and murmurs into her ear.
Tell me this isn’t all some big fat joke.
It’s real, Darling. Breathe. They give each other a quick kiss and Joe turns back to h people.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 10.

Okay, let’s do this! Joan watches Joe and Hal head to the library. We see them from Joan’s P.O.V., through the open door as the TIMES PHOTOGRAPHER directs Joe to stand with his arms crossed, the stance of a literary giant. She turns to go back to t party but she can’t face the writer’s wives who’ve been watching her with their sad, resentful faces.

Joan has escaped to the kitchen where CATERERS are settin more food out on trays. She’s poured herself a glass of wine. We see her daughter SUSANNAH (30), a capable young woman who’s hugely pregnant, setting champagne flutes on tray.
Mom, when do you want to bring out the champagne?
Oh, I don’t know. The sooner the better. Then they'll all go home. Joan puts her hands on her daughter’s big belly.
Hello my baby’s baby, I’m ready for a nap.
Poor, Mommy. Joan's son DAVID (28) wanders in with an expensive box of cigars tucked under his arm. He's a tortured young man, w has Joe's handsomeness and intelligence but none of his aplomb.
Hello, Lamb, there you are.
Yeah, sorry I'm late. I was looking for some decent cigars to give to Dad.
I didn’t get him anything. Was I supposed to?
No, Honey, he’s been lavished enough. Susannah gives her little brother a hug.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 11.
Hey monkey.
Hey Sis. (patting her belly) Hello, Little Man.

Yeah?

Honey, are you hungry? Go get something to eat. Joan watches her troubled son wander back out to the livi room. David walks by the buffet table, where Joe’s writer frien are still pawing over the food. Dusty Berkowitz corners h  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 12.

Joan pulls out a hand-tinted post card, circa 1927, of so young college women doing a skit, the caption: Northrop H Follies, Smith College.
Oh, Northrop House. That was my dorm.
I know. The picture's a bit before your time, but I thought you'd get a kick out of it. Joan is impressed by the gift but doesn't entirely trust Bone.
Thank you, Nathanial, this was very thoughtful.

Well, you've always been very kind to me during my aborted attempts to woo Joe. Listen, there’s a great bar here, very nineteenth century. You can imagine Strinberg getting hammered there. Can I buy you a drink?
Oh, I don't know how appropriate that would be.

It’s completely inappropriate. But we're in Sweden in the dead of winter and I don’t think either of us should be left alone to our own brooding thoughts, do you? Bone is actually flirting with her. Joan finds it rather enjoyable. Joe would be appalled. And that’s why she says...
One drink. No more.
35 Joan and Bone are now sitting in a quaint, wood panelled tavern. It's a cozy, intimate place, good for losing one' sobriety. They're both having icy, vodka-based drinks.
..-listen, I want you to know that I’ve gotten an offer to write a book about Joe. I wanted to tell you so you don’t think I’m doing anything behind his back.
And is this going to be a scholarly work?
Yes and no.
Meaning what?
Please don't take offense, but you might as well know that I'm aware of Joe's various indiscretions.
(unruf fled) I'm sure you are. I imagine it's all very juicy material for a biographer.

To be honest, it's a little predictable. Most of your men of genius seem to have overactive libidos. And thanks to the worshipful tomes put out by us biographers, we're supposed to find it all very charming and forgivable. I don't, actually. I think that kind of behavior is rather appalling.
Please don't paint me as a victim. I'm much more interesting than that.
Oh, I know you are. Look, I don’t want to make the wrong assumptions about your relationship. So why don't you set me straight?
Oh Nathanial, you're so trans- parent. I can't believe I let you lure me here.  36 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 56.

Of course you're free to get up and leave this cozy cafe and these excellent drinks and spend the rest of the afternoon in some drafty museum of obscure Nordic art. Joan takes a careful sip of her drink.
All right. You have an hour with me.
Thank you, Joan. I really do appreciate this. And if there's anything you don't want to talk about, feel free to tell me to fuck off.
Oh, don't worry, I will.

We're on stage where WORKMEN are arranging giant stands o flowers to frame the ceremony. A TELEVISION CREW is setti up for the broadcast. James Finch and the other LAUREATES are gathered on stage a rehearsal. They’re all chatting amicably among themselv while the NOBEL ORGANIZERS and ASSISTANTS stand on the sidelines, watching them in delight. Joe arrives with Walter in tow.

Mister Castleman, let me introduce you to your fellow laureates. Gentlemen, this is Joseph Castleman who is to receive the Nobel Prize in literature. The other laureates pause in their conversations and turn Joe. They all shake hands as they’re introduced. WALTER (CONT’D) Professor Finch, you have already met...this is Professor Chen Ling who's receiving the prize in chemistry...Doctor Karl Seigler, our esteemed laureate in medicine...and Sir Randall Meade who's receiving the prize in economics.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 57. Joe, intimidated by all this brilliance, is grinning and hunting around for something pithy to say.

Well, to quote Groucho Marx, “I never want to be a member of a club that would have me.” However, with this crowd I’d be an idiot not to make an exception. Hearty laughter from the great men. Linnea is there with her camera. She takes a few quick sh to capture this moment, then gives Joe a wink.
I will turn you over to Mr. Lagerfelt who will instruct you on the protocol for tomorrow’s ceremony. The impeccable MR. LAGERFELT steps forward.

Gentlemen, you will be entering from this side of the stage, in this order: Sir Meade, Professor Finch, Mr.Castleman, Professor Ling and Doctor Seigler. You will take your seats here, indicated, for now, by these signs with your names. When it is your time to receive your medal, you will walk from your seat, to here. And you will receive your medal from the King. Mr. Lagerfelt demonstrates with an OLDER GENTLEMAN who’s standing in for the king and gives him the medal box. MR. LAGERFELT (CONT’D) You shall then bow, making the three reverences. Like so. We will start with you Mr. Castleman. Joe, feeling the other laureates’ eyes on him, can’t focu
I’m sorry -- do I bow first?
You approach the king and then you bow.
Ah -- sorry.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 58.
No need to apologize. That is why we are practicing.

It’s not rocket science, Castleman! The other laureates chuckle good-naturedly but Joe grimac bit. He approaches the gentleman playing the king who han him a stand-in for the box with the Nobel medal. Linnea i clicking away, her camera feeling a little too close.

And now the three reverences. Joe awkwardly bows in the three directions as Linnea continues to take her shots -- click...click...click.... MR. LAGERFELT (CONT’D) Very good Mr. Castleman, you may now return to your seat. Joe is sweating.
If you'll excuse me for a moment...
(hovering) Are you feeling all right, Mr. Castleman?
I just need to take a break, excuse me.
Can I bring you some water?
I'm fine, I’m fine. Thank you. Carry on! Joe walks off the stage.
Bone is getting out his cigarettes -- foreign, of course. offers one to Joan.
Do you smoke?
Not officially.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 59.
I would guess that Joe made you give it up.
Yes, he wants to keep me healthy. Joan takes a cigarette. Bone lights it for her. There’s a hint of seduction in the gesture. Bone pulls out a notebook.
May I?
Go ahead.
First fascinating query -- this is the publisher's not mine: "What does the Nobel Prize mean to Joseph Castleman?"
Oh God.
What if I just quote what he said to me on the plane, "it's not about the prize, it's about getting up the gumption to write the next book."
Perfect. Thank you.
And what about you? How do you get up the gumption?
To get up in the morning?
To write.
I'm not a writer, Nathanial.

I beg to differ. When I was looking through the Smith archives I found some of your stories that were published in the college journal. I read "The Faculty Wife." It’s a beautifully written piece.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 60.
Thank you, but the fact is I had potential and nothing more.
And you don't regret giving it up?
No, I had very low expectations of what I could accomplish as a female writer.
But there were plenty of successful women writers back then.
A few. But I didn’t have the right personality for it.
Really.
I’m quite shy. I don’t like to be looked at.
All right, I won’t look at you.
How kind. Joan takes a sip of her drink.
Did Joe encourage you to keep writing?
Yes, but as I said, I didn't choose to pursue it.
Because he was the writer of the family.
Now Nathanial, if you’re trolling for nuggets of bitterness you'll find none here.
Speaking of bitterness, I've talked to his ex, Carol.
How is she doing?  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 61.
She's a psychiatrist.
Oh. Good for her. And their daughter, Fanny?
She's a dentist. Carol forgives you, by the way.
I'm glad. Joe tried to keep in contact with them...I urged him to. We both feel very badly about that chapter of our lives.
She said to thank you for taking him off her hands.
She’s welcome. Joan takes a drag of her cigarette, taps the ash. Bone is watching her.
I hope you know that Joe’s affairs don’t have anything to do with you. It’s a compulsion. I believe it’s a part of his deep-seated fear of inadequacy.
Well, aren't you the therapist.
Do you have anyone that you confide in?
No. But I don't really care to.
And that's what makes you so attractive. Your mystery.
My God, Nathanial, are you flirting with me?
Oh, probably. Why not?
You know I don't trust you.  38 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 62.
Of course you don't. I'ma writer on a deadline, why should you? The waiter comes by and sets down a little plate of Swedi meatballs.
Would you like another drink?
One is my limit, thank you.
Oh come on. I’m having another.
No, Nathanial. Nathanial signals to the waiter to bring two more.

location: STOCKHOLM CONCERT HALL, CHAMBER ROOM-- DAY 38

text: Joe has wandered into a formal, re-carpeted chamber that surrounded on all sides by doors and mirrors. He looks around it, disorientated.

Mr. Castleman? Joe turns and sees Linnea. She holds her hands up to show that she doesn’t have her cameras with her. LINNEA (CONT’D) I come to you unarmed. I could see that I was getting on your nerves. All that clicking in your face. I do apologize.
No apologies necessary, it’s your job.
They told me that if you wish, they will release you for the day.
I wish that, yes. (looking at all the doors) Which one of these offers the quickest escape?
Shall we try them and see? There my be a secret passageway.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 63.
Or a dead end.
We must choose carefully.
Indeed. They stand there together, playing this little game, the sexual tension between them palpable.
May I confess something.
Go ahead.
I am usually very objective about my subjects. But you move me. Very much.
Do I.

You have a wonderful face. Linnea cups Joe’s head in her hands and peers into his fa eyes shining. She touches his strong, high brow, the line on his forehead, evidence of all that genius... LINNEA (CONT’D) Your mind...where does it all come from? Joe can see that she wants to be kissed. How can he resis her luscious young lips or the comforting territory of a young acolyte’s ass. BEE-BEE, BEE-BEE. The alarm on Joe's watch has gone off.
Oh shit. He starts fiddling with his watch, trying to turn it off.
Shit. My pills.
Your pills?
For my blood pressure.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 64.
Do you need to take them?
I think I should head back to the hotel.
Yes, all right. Joe is dying. He wants to get out of there. He pulls a walnut out of his pocket and offers it up to her.
Here -- Joe gets out a pen and starts writing on it.
To Linnea -- that's L-I-N-E-A..
No, two N's.
Two N's. Joe tries to rub the letters out.
That’s all right -- I should go. Do you know the way out?
Yes. I’m fine. Go ahead. Linnea makes a hasty exit, leaving Joe holding the walnut feeling like an utter fool.
Aw shit.
Joan has made a healthy dent in her second drink. She and Bone are lighting up another cigarette.
You know, I'm curious about something. Off the record.
Off the record -- we’ve all heard that one before.
On my honor.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 65. Bone puts his note pad down.
I've read some of Joe's early work - - some short stories I dug up ina couple of obscure literary journals. I hate to say it, but they weren't so great.
Early work is rarely very readable, I think you know that.
But there isn't even a hint of his mature voice. In fact your piece, "The Faculty Wife" reads more like early Castleman than these do.
That doesn’t surprise me. Joe had a very heavy hand as a teacher.
Fair enough, but when I talked to Carol, she said it was odd how his writing got so much better after he met you.
That’s very generous of her.

With all respect, I think you're tired of his affairs, tired of being invisible, tired of putting your enormous talent into creating the Castleman legend. And for the health of your family, this might be something you'd want to do. David seems like a very unhappy young man.
You have no business talking about my children.

No, you’re right. I apologize. (gently) I think you really do want to talk. And I give you my word, I'll never reveal my source. I’1ll be the bad guy so you don’t have to feel like you're betraying Joe. The truth will be out and then you'd be free to write on your own.  40 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 66.
What a marvelous story, Nathaniel. You really ought to write fiction. Joan gets up.
You know where to find me. And Joan, I want you to know -- I really do enjoy your company. Joan gives Bone one of her gracious, elusive smiles and s leaves him there to stew over his drink.
Joan, looking rattled, is now letting herself into the su We hear Joe calling.
Joan?! Joanie ?! Is that you?!
Yes. Joe appears, half-dressed in his boxer shorts and dress shirt.
Where have you been? I've been worried sick.
Joe, it's only four-thirty.
But look how dark it is already! Don't do this to me, don't disappear on me like that.
I didn't disappear. I was gone for a few hours.
What did you do all day?
I walked around, visited shops.
You’ve had a cigarette. I can smell it on you.
I stopped at a cafe. It was filled with smoke.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 67.
You’ve been drinking too.
I had a vodka.
In the middle of the day?
Yes, Joe, in the middle of the day. Joan makes her way through the suite to the master bedroo Joe following.
You need to pace yourself. You shouldn't be showing up at these functions with alcohol on your breath.
You’re the one who’s the star of the show, why would anyone possibly care?
What the hell's gotten into you?
I don't like you lecturing me. I'm not a child. Joe has left his pants and shirt in a heap on the floor. Joan starts picking them up.
Dammit, Joe, would you not leave your clothes on the floor? I'm sick of picking up after you.
Leave it. Here, lemme have it. As Joe grabs his pants from Joan the walnut falls out of pocket.
What's that? Joe moves in, picks it up.
I was hungry, I bought some walnuts.
Let me see it.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 68.
Come on, Joanie.
Let me see it. Joan grabs at the walnut. Joe tries to keep it away. They wrestle over it like a couple of ten-year-olds.
What're you doing? You're acting crazy. Joan pries the walnut out of Joe's hand. She stares at th half-completed inscription.
So while I was out being the drunken lush, you, the picture of sobriety, were seducing the luscious young Linnea.
Nothing happened. Joan hurls the walnut at Joe. It hits him smack in the middle of his forehead.
Ow! Jesus, Joanie.
Don't insult my intelligence, don't you dare.
Nothing happened! I was the one who stopped it.
Well bully for you.

Yes bully for me! You know why I stopped? Because I was thinking about you sitting on some fucking tour bus, feeling neglected, with no one to talk to and I rushed back here so you wouldn't be sitting here all alone! And then I end up waiting for you!
So sorry, Joe, I should've let you know I'd be late so you could finish screwing your photographer.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 69.
I wasn't going to screw her, God dammit. I’m not even attracted to the fucking woman. In fact all I could think about was getting back to you.
I'm touched. The phone is ringing.
You think I'm proud of my behavior? It sickens me. I’m too old for this shit! I’m done! I’m all yours.
Well goody for me. Joan picks up the phone.
(into phone) Hello?
Hi Mom.
Susannah.
I had the baby.
Oh! Joe! Susannah had her baby!
Oh my God!
Get on the other line! Joe runs to the library and grabs the phone by the toilet
Oh Sweetie, when did this happen?
A couple of hours ago. I’m looking at him right now. He’s beautiful. Mark is holding him. He’s making little mewling sounds.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 70.
It’s a boy?! You had a boy?! What’d you name him?
Max.
Who does he look like?
Dad, I know you want me to say that he looks like you, but right now he just looks like a very sweet baby.
Put the phone next to his ear, I want to say hello.
Hold on...Mark take the phone, Dad wants to talk to the baby...
Is he on? We hear snuffling on the other end.
Hello Maxwell, how ya doing? It’s your grandpa Joe, whatta ya know?
Hello, beautiful boy, it’s Grandma. Hello. More snuffling.
He’s talking to us, you hear that?
You are the sweetest boy in all the world. Oh I wish I had you in my arms right now. We hear the phone being handed back.
Dad, Mom, I have to go. Mark’s parents just got here. We can hear the other grandparents gushing over the baby.
Give that Max a big kiss for us, will you?  41
I will.
We love you, sweetheart. We love you very much.
Love you too. Bye bye. 71. Joan and Joe hang up. Joe comes back into the bedroom. Jo is already starting to cry. Joe puts his arms around her.
Aw Joanie, it doesn’t any get better than this. Say what you will about the crap we put each other through -- we still have a wonderful fucking life.

4l The Castlemans and Joe’s entourage are all in the bar whi has been taken over by all the Laureates who are now all happily getting drunk. Joe, still glowing from the news of his grandchild is sit with David, full of affection for his son. They’re both leaning together, deep in conversation while Joan sits ba sipping a cognac, glad to see the two of them making amen
You're a gifted writer David, you are.
Thank you, Dad. I appreciate that.
I liked your story. It’s well structured.
But...
There’s always a but with a first draft. Come on, you know that. You want to hear this?
Sure, yeah, go on.
I don’t completely buy what you did with the couple -- the blowhard husband, the stoic wife with the (MORE)
repressed rage. We’ve seen it. It’s a cliche. You can do better.
Okay...Jesus.
It’s part of the process, David. It’s painful, I know. Writing is a fucking agony.
Yes Darling, it’s dreadful. You suffer enormously. Joe gives Joan a curious look.
Time for bed. I’m taking your mother to bed. Have a good night, Boyo, don’t stay up too late.

Good night, Darling. Call your sister. She’d love to hear from you. Joe and Joan leave to a chorus of ebullient good nights. STAY ON David as he watches his parents walk away, his fa affectionately supporting his elegant, tipsy mother, his squeezing her waist. They’re going to have celebratory se no doubt. David sees Ellen Finch sitting with her brother Sam at a table. She looks up expectantly to David, eager to have h join her. David can’t face this girl with her crush on hi and pretends not to see her. He pats his pockets for cigarettes but he’s all out. He g over to the bar and mimes a cigarette to the Swedish bartender.
Cigaretten?
(in perfect English) I’m very sorry Sir, we don’t sell them here.
Here, you can have one of mine. David turns and sees Bone who’s discreetly tucked himself at the bar.  42 43 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 73.
Oh. Hey. Bone offers David his pack of cigarettes.
Thanks. They both light up and look over at a table where Ellen a Sam Finch are huddled together drinking beers.
I’ve been watching them. The girl chews her hair and the other one has a tic.
Yeah, they’re pretty screwed up.
Aren’t we all. My dad taught at Yale. He made me recite the Iliad at the dinner table. In Greek.
That’s really fucked up.
You want to know what’s really, really fucked up? He didn’t understand a fucking word of it. They laugh and light up.
So what’re you drinking?

Joe is out cold, softly snoring in the billows of the eiderdown. Joan, wide awake, is sitting in the library sipping a bra waiting to fall asleep. She stares at all the Castleman books that are displayed on the shelf. She pulls out THE WALNUT. It’s a slim book, with a simple, classy cover des that says to the world, this is an IMPORTANT book. Joan opens it up to the dedication: TO J., IN AWE. J.

EXTREME CLOSE ON young Joan reading something. We see the reflection of the pages in her eyes as her pupils flick f word to word.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 74. She turns the last page over and lets out a long, despair sigh. She taps the pages back together, into a neat stack CLOSE ON the title page: THE WALNUT. Young Joe comes bursting through the door.

Okay, I walked to Harlem and back, had five espressos, and made my way through a pack and a half of cigarettes. He sits down on the bed with her, sees his manuscript. It been read. Good. YOUNG JOE (CONT’D) So? What do you think? Joan is in agony. She can't speak. Joe is hoping this mea that she's struck dumb by his brilliance. YOUNG JOE (CONT’D) What. Tell me.
Look. You asked me to be honest.
So talk.
I'm really, really sorry, Joe, but it doesn't work for me.
What do you mean?
Somehow...it never really comes alive. I wanted more than anything to be moved. But I wasn't. I'm sorry.
It's because the subject is too close to you. I should get a more objective opinion.
The characters are wooden, Joe. No offense, but you haven't made them real.
That doesn't mean anything. Get specific.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 75.
Well the dialogue, for one thing ...Um, it's stilted. (nervously flipping through the pages) Let me see if I can find an example...
Fuck this. This isn't going to work.
What isn't?
This whole thing. You and me. This love affair of ours, whatever you want to call it.
Joe, just because I don't like your novel doesn't mean that I don't love you --
Of course it does. How can you love me if you think I'm a hack? Joan is starting to cry.
Joe, please!
How can I be with someone who has no respect for me?
I do respect you! I respect you in all kinds of ways!
"All kinds of ways"?! Fuck that! Tell me that you believe in me as a writer!
It's only your first draft, Joe!
Screw it, Joanie, it's over. Joan is now a sobbing wreck.
Oh God! No, Joe, it can't be over!
This relationship is doomed!
We're not doomed!
What am I supposed to do, go back and teach English at some second- rate college? Since obviously I just blew it with the Ivy Leagues by screwing one of my students.
I'm not just one of your students!
No, you're the girl with the golden touch! You'll go on to be the literary sensation while I stay at home grading papers and cooking the pot roast!

I'm not going to be a literary sensation, you bastard! Not ever! No one will ever publish my books! And if they do, no one will read them! I'll end up like Elaine Mozell, bitter and angry and drunk! This declaration somehow calms Joe down a bit. YOUNG JOAN (CONT’D) I'm not full of big ideas the way you are! You're the brilliant one! You're the one who has something to say, not me! Please don't leave me, please. If I lose you, my life is over! Joe sits on the bed with Joan and holds her. He starts crying as well.
I'm not going anywhere, shush.
I don't want to live without you!

I don't want to live without you either. Oh Joanie, life is so fucking unfair They both hold on to each other for a beat madly kissing weeping.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 77. YOUNG JOE (CONT’D) Okay, okay, let’s try to calm down. We’ll be okay. Joe gets out his hankie. They both share it, wiping off their tears.
What are we going to do?
I dunno. Lemme think. Joe gets out the cigarettes and hands one to Joan. They b light up. YOUNG JOE (CONT’D) So you think it hopeless, this piece of shit I wrote?

It's not a piece of shit, Joe. It's a really compelling story. The ideas are all there. I know how to fix it. I can see it. (a beat) Do you want me to fix it? A long beat. YOUNG JOAN (CONT’D) Do you Joe?
Go ahead. Make it yours.

Joan and Joe are dressed and ready to go -- Joe in white and tails and Joan in an elegant evening gown with jewels her throat. She’s touching up the maturing walnut bruise Joe's forehead with base from her compact.
Where the hell is he?
Joe, relax.
If he doesn’t show up, that’s it. We're going without him. The buzzer is ringing.
You see? There he is.
(the bruise) How do I look? Can you tell?
It looks fine. Don’t touch it. Joan goes to the door and lets David in, who’s dressed in tux.
Hello, Darling. Look how handsome you are.
You’re late. We better get going. (nervously patting his pockets ) ...where're my glasses? Joanie, you have my glasses?
They're in my purse.
You have the invitations?
I don’t think we’ll need them.
You never know. David is rummaging in one of the fruit baskets.
David, c’mere, your bow tie is all wrong, let me fix it.
No, I have it.
You don't know how to tie it. C’mere. David starts moving away.
Come on, stand still. Joe pulls David's bow tie apart and starts to re-tie it. sniffs at David’s collar.
(pulling away) What’re you doing.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 79.
You've been smoking pot.
No I haven't.
Yes you have, you reek of it!
Joe, calm down.
No, I won’t! Look at him. He’s completely stoned! (to David) What the hell is the matter with you?
I guess I’m a real embarrassment to you, huh Pop?
What kind of hostile crap is that?
Joe. (evenly) David, what's going on? David starts trying to fix his tie.
I don’t know, Mom, I’m trying to figure out if I’ve been worshipping at the wrong parental shrine.
What the hell are you talking about? David just shakes his head, stays focused on the tie.
(to Joan) He’s a mess. What are we supposed to do with him?
I’m not a pronoun, Pop, I’m standing right here.
Then talk to us, for Chrissakes!
Joe, don’t shout at him.
Yes I will. We’re late! We're supposed to be in the limo right now and he’s already spoiling my night with this bullshit.
Is it?
Is it what?
Your night. Because according to your biographer this could all be some brilliant fraud.
What biographer?
That guy on the plane, with the glasses and the hair, Andy Warhol with pigment.
Nathaniel Bone? He’s not my fucking biographer! What’re you talking about?
He was in the bar last night.
David, what did he say to you?
He said I shouldn’t measure myself against my venerable father’s success because there’s a theory that you, my mother, are the real genius of the family.
David, that’s ridiculous.
Why would he make such a twisted thing up?
Don’t be an idiot, David. He’s out to get me because I won't authorize his hack-job on my life.
I’m not an idiot! Why would you call me that?  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 81.
All right, calm down.
But of course, if what he said is true, then I’d really be a fucking idiot wouldn’t I?
You’re not an idiot, David.
I don’t mean to state the obvious, but I think the pot is making you paranoid.
I’m not fucking paranoid!
Honey, Nathanial Bone is an unscrupulous man and he had no right to tell you these things.
He said he had a drink with you. Did you? The air very briefly goes out of the room. Joe looks at J
I did. He approached me in the lobby and I didn’t think it was wise to rebuff him.
He said that you confessed.
Confessed what?
He said that you ghostwrite dad's books.
I never said that.
Do you?
No, David, I don't.
I don't believe you.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 82.
(with great calm) I can’t make you believe me, Honey. It’s up to you what you believe.
David, these are lies. It’s fucking outrageous.
Okay. But let me just ask you something, Dad. Why were the two of you always closing the door on me with her inside? What the fuck was she doing in there?
What’re you talking about?
The fucking door to your office! It was always being slammed in my face! With the two of you inside --
Your mother was proofreading.
I DON’T FUCKING BELIEVE YOU! David grabs the gift card from the box of chocolates.

head_text.subj: YOU ASKED MOM WHO THE HELL IS

text: SYLVIA FRY! YOU DON’T EVEN KNOW
David kicks over a table, sending Joe’s gift baskets and chocolates flying.
That’s enough now, David, that’s enough! David starts shoving Joe against the wall.

head_text.subj: MADE A SLAVE OF MY MOTHER

text: (scared now) Okay...okay...
David, stop, you have to calm down. Your father doesn’t control me. I’m fine.  45 46 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 83. David starts sobbing.
This is all so fucked up...I'm sorry...
Listen, I know it's not easy being my son. I know that.
Ma...
It’s all right, Darling. Joan puts her arms around David and he sobs against her chest.
Look, we’ve all been under a lot of pressure. And you're exhausted. You haven't slept in what, three days? Joe pats David's back.
Listen, why don't you skip the ceremony, get some rest. Take the night off, order up some food. That sound good to you? Joe looks at Joan in agony but she can’t meet his eyes.
Joe and Joan are sitting apart from each other in silence There’s still a slight wet spot on Joan’s gown from David crying fit.
We're not bad people, Joanie. Joan has nothing to say to this. They drive on.

We see Young Joan sitting at her large wrap-around desk i front of a typewriter while Young Joe stands behind her, massaging her shoulders. The two of them are looking down her pages that Joe has marked up with red pencil.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 84.
This part where you describe her folding his clothes, it goes on too long. The office door opens and THREE-YEAR-OLD DAVID slips in carrying a little stuffed giraffe.

It’s deliberate, Joe. It’s about her boredom while she’s waiting for him to show up. David goes over to Joan and leans against her and starts bouncing the giraffe around her desk. YOUNG JOAN (CONT’D) There’s a rhythm to it. Do you see? It’s an endless list of the prosaic.
I see it. It’s good. If that’s what you’re doing, you need to take it further then. Joan holds her hand up to Joe.
I have it. Joan starts typing. David, wanting Joan’s attention, wags giraffe in front of her face. YOUNG JOAN (CONT’D) Sweetie...

(to David) C’'mere, Kiddo. Joe picks David up and walks him back to the door. He cal out to the hall. YOUNG JOE (CONT’D) Melinda...? Through the door, we see Joe hand David off to their nann MELINDA, a young woman who’s not beautiful but pleasant enough that Joe might feel compelled to seduce her. He sh the door behind him and we hear David crying in protest. Joan looks up from her typing as the sound of David’s cri fade as he’s being led away. She stares at the closed doo for a beat -- was that my child crying? Joan returns to h typing...
47 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 85.
Mr. Castleman, you have given us a vast, restless and brilliant body of work...

We see Dr. Ekeberg standing at the podium on the grand No stage delivering his ode to Joe. On one side of the stage KING GUSTAV OF SWEDEN, QUEEN SYLVIA, and the elderly CROW PRINCESS VICTORIA who are in their full royal regalia -- medals, ribbons, tiaras and all. On the other side We see Joe sitting with his fellow laureates, along with the solemn MEMBERS OF THE ACADEMY w are there to bear witness to his lionization.

With each book, Mr. Castleman, you have challenged the novelistic form and reinvented the very nature of storytelling and of prose. You are a master of style, yet your characters are intensely real, their journeys heartbreaking, their portrayals intimate and deep. We see Joan, sitting with the other LAUREATE FAMILIES. Ne to her is David’s empty seat. She’s staring at the stage, listening to this man talking about her work, her voice, gift. Up in the peanut gallery we see Nathaniel Bone in his ren tux madly taking notes in his pad with a gleeful little g on his face.

The humanity in your writing transcends the boundaries of class and gender. You are a master of words, but more importantly, you are a master at portraying the human condition in all it’s complexities. CLOSE ON Joe. We see that he’s dying inside but trying to maintain an expression of quiet dignity.

Mr. Castleman, I would like to convey to you the warm congratulations of the Swedish Academy as I now request you to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature from his Majesty the King.  48 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 86. As Joe rises from his seat all the notables on stage rise with him, including the royals. Everyone in the concert hall rises as well, in a great wh of tuxes and gowns. Constance Finch who’s so pleased and proud for all of the reaches over to Joan and give her hand a little squeeze. There’s a reverent hush as Joe makes his way across the s to King Gustav. Joe bows his head to the King. King Gustav says a few laudatory words to him then hands him the Nobel medal whi is housed in a flat leather box. As they shake hands, a FANFARE sounds and Joe numbly makes his three reverences. And Joan joins the audience in applauding her husband's g achievement.

location: STOCKHOLM CITY HALL, THE BLUE HALL

text: We’re now at the Nobel banquet which is housed in a vast, glittering, two-story hall. Rows of mile-long tables have been elaborately set with flowers, candelabra, and crysta wine glasses to accommodate the plethora of toasts. Seate at the tables are SWEDISH and INTERNATIONAL VIP’S and the patient WIVES, all talking loudly, intoxicated by the eve and the generous amount of wine being served. We see Joan and Joe sitting across from each other at the table of honor with King Gustav and Queen Sylvia. Joe, ju trying to get through the night, has slipped back into hi role as the charming raconteur. He’s been across the tabl from the two royals who are both hanging on to his every word. Joan is between the King and a DIPLOMAT who's conversing with the WOMAN on his other side. Having no on to talk to, she’s staying engaged with her wine.
«+.SO you brown the brisket in the pot and then you add two cups of water, some ketchup, some garlic salt, and here's the secret ingredient -- a tablespoon of instant coffee.
Really. This is a typical recipe of the American Jewish culture?

No it's a typical reflection of what a terrible cook my mother was. The King guffaws.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 87. Joan smiles, drinks down her wine. A uniformed SERVER com by and Joan gratefully lets him refill her glass. A NOBEL HOSTESS approaches Joe and the King with great deference.
Excuse me, Your Majesty, if I may lead Mr. Castleman to the dais.
Yes, of course.
(to his table mates) Excuse me. I shall return.

Yes, bravo, please do. As Joe gets up, he stares across the table at Joan. They eyes for a beat and it’s possible, just possible, that he ready to tell the world. Joe moves off without another word, leaving Joan breathle She takes a healthy gulp of her wine to possibly prepare herself. King Gustav politely turns to Joan. KING GUSTAV (CONT’D) Tell me about yourself Mrs. Castleman. Do you have an occupation?
Yes I do.
And what is that?
I'm a king-maker. A beat. The king finally gets it.

You know, my wife will tell you the same thing. They both share a jolly chuckle. Up in the balcony, four TRUMPETERS play a fanfare. The Nobel Hostess is standing at a podium that's set at t top of a grand staircase. She addresses the guests in Swedish and then again in English:  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 88.

Your Majesties, Your Royal Highness, Ladies and Gentlemen. It is a great honor to introduce the Nobel prize winner in literature, Mr. Joseph Castleman. To great applause, Joe mounts the stairs to the podium. H stares down at all the expectant faces: his proud team beaming up at him, Linnea with her camera ready, his fell Laureates looking at him with their deeply intelligent ey Joe's mouth has gone dry. He licks his lips.
Good evening and thank you to the Swedish Academy and Your Majesty for your kind welcome and this magnificent feast. I am deeply grateful for this honor you have given me. Joe pauses.
But really this honor belongs to someone else. My wife Joan. There's a great rustling as everyone in the hall shifts i their seats to look at Joan. Joan girds herself.

Joan is truly my better half. She has made it possible for me to find the stillness, as well as the noise, to create my body of work. Without her, I am certain I would not be standing up here tonight. I would instead be at home staring at a blank piece of paper with my mouth open in stupification. Warm laughter.

She has been my sanity, my conscience, the inspiration for every decent impulse that I've ever had. Joan, you are my muse, my love, my soul. And I share this honor with you. King Gustav stands, cuing the guests to all rise to their feet to applaud the lovely Joan. Joan can’t believe that just reduced her to the wife yet again. She’s livid but s maintains her cool and obligingly mouths her thank-you’s the adoring crowd.  49 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 89.

Joe now returning to the table. The King and all of his jolly table mates give him a round of applause. Joe goes over to Joan and gives her a kiss. She can’t bea to look at him. We hear another trumpet fanfare and the lights in the hal are dimmed. An orchestra starts playing a processional as column of SERVERS enter, carrying enormous platters mound with an elaborate concoction of sherbets and spun sugar. Joan picks up her purse and gets up from the table.
Where're you going?

I’m leaving. Joe starts following Joan as she makes her ways between t rows of tables and diners. Joe takes Joan by the elbow an tries to steer her away from servers who are now marching either side of them with their giant dessert trays. Joan trips a little in her heels. Joe catches her.
Joanie, slow down. Joan jerks away from Joe and stumbles into one of the ser causing his tray to upend, spilling the dessert, sherbets all, on Joan's gown.

Oh Christ. The server, aghast, starts making mad apologies in Swedis Diners are turning around. A few GENTLEMAN jump up and of Joan their napkins. An army of STAFF swoop in to attend to Joan and the mess the floor. Joe is speechless with humiliation. Mrs. Lindelof appears and starts ushering Joe and Joan ou the hall.
Come, my dear, come, I will take you to the powder room.
I want to go back to the hotel.  50
I think my wife would like to change. Where is our car?
This way...
50 Joan, walking ahead of Joe and Mrs. Lindelof, is now maki her way down the snow-blown steps of the City Hall to whe the limos are waiting.
Joanie, wait up, you’re gonna freeze out here Joe pulls off his tuxedo jacket and throws it over her shoulders.
Mrs. Castleman, if you tell me your dress size, I can have a clean gown delivered to you.
Thank you, but I’m done for the night. Walter breathlessly joins them, carrying the Nobel medal its box.
Mr. Castleman. You left this on the table!
Ah. Thank you.
Mrs. Castleman, we're so very sorry this happened.
I think I’1l ride with her.
Of course. But you'll be coming back, yes?
We'll see. Gustav is jumping out of the limo and opening the door fo the Castlemans.  51
Joe gets in the car with Joan. Gustav slams the runs to his side. We watch the limo take off.
Joan is shivering. Joe is rubbing her arms.
Gustav, would you turn up the heat? And can you give us a little privacy? Thank you. The privacy screen glides up. Joe turns back to
Listen, we'll go to the hotel, you'll change, we’ll go back, make a quick appearance and then we’1l be done with this whole fucking thing.
I’m leaving you Joe.
What are you talking about?
I can’t do this anymore.
Come on, this is crazy. You're not going to leave me.
Please don't act furious, or heartbroken, or shocked, none of which you could possibly be.
Look, I know you didn’t want me to acknowledge you in my speech. But do think what I said up there was all for show? I meant every word of it. Give me some credit.
For what?
For loving you.
God, Joe.
What. 91. door and 51 Joan.  52 53 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 92. Joan just shakes her head and stares out the window. Joe takes the Nobel medal out of the box offers it to Joa
Here.
I don’t want it.
It belongs to you.
No.
Quit being so stubborn. Take it. Take it!
It’s yours Joe, all yours.
I don’t want the fucking thing! Joe takes the medal and throws it out the window. They look at each other in brief, delighted, shock. Then bangs on the partition.
Gustav -- stop the car.
The limo is pulled over and we see Joe and Gustav walking the busy boulevard digging in a snow bank for the medal.

Joe and Joan are now walking into their hushed suite. The voluminous curtains have been drawn making the place feel bit like a funeral parlor. Joan throws her evening purse on a table and Joe flings t Nobel medal next to it. Joan starts heading down the hall
Joan. Joanie... Joe catches her and pulls her into the library.
Joanie, c’'mere. Sit so I can look at you. Do you want a drink?
No.
Listen to me. There's nothing horrible or shameful or immoral about what we do. We're writing partners. We’ve created a beautiful body of work together.
You edit, Joe, that's all you do. I'm the one who’s sits at the desk six hours a day.

That’s how you see it? Really? You're saying that all these years you've been sitting in some giant stew of resentment. Okay, and how about all the years I’ve been rubbing your back and bringing you tea and cooking your dinner and watching the kids so you could work without distraction -- you don’t think there were times when it fucking killed me that you were the one with the golden touch? You think I wake up every morning feeling even remotely proud of myself? But have I ever said to you, I’m done with this marriage, I’m walking away?
No, you had affairs.
And I’ve regretted every fucking one of them!

Oh yes, you'd sob in my lap and beg me to forgive you, and I always would because somehow you convinced me that my talent made you do it. And if I felt too hurt and furious to write, you’d give me one of your famous back rubs and say, “use it, Joanie, use it.”
I never said that.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 94.

You did Joe! And lucky me, I had somewhere to put it. The critics loved the image of Sylvia Fry scrubbing the tear stains out of her good silk dress after a fight wit her lover. “Another Castleman masterpiece.” And your chest swelled, it actually swelled, and instead of being outraged and saying “enough I can’t do this anymore!”, I remember thinking to myself, “how can I describe that.” And you know what? I did! Joan pulls a Castleman book out of the bookshelf.
Here it is in another Castleman masterpiece! Joan tosses the book at the floor and pulls out another b
Oh and look. This one I wrote after you screwed our, what was it? Third nanny!
That book has nothing to do with the fucking nanny!
Oh yes it did!
Bullshit! (grabbing the book from her. ) These are MY stories, MY culture, MY family, MY ideas!
MY words! MY pain! MY hours of sitting alone at the desk, neglecting our children and turning your appalling behavior into literary gold!

Fuck you, Joanie, fuck you! What did you ever have to say that was so goddamn compelling? You were nothing but a privileged, prissy little co-ed. The only decent story you ever wrote on your own was about Carol! You stole from my life even then.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 95.
Shame on you, Joe. Joan shoves past Joe and heads for the bedroom.

(following her) You wanted this! You loved holing up in the Village with the big, bad Jew. You loved making your parents squirm. You love that you got the literary life and still get the house by the sea and the nice clothes and the travelling and all the privileges without having to Marry some schmuck at a brokerage firm. You got it all, my girl.
Take it back, I don’t want it. Joan is packing her suitcase.
What're you doing?
I’m spending the night in David's room. And when I get home I’m calling a lawyer.

Joanie come on, you’re not leaving me. We have our kids and a grandson and friends we've known forever who will start dying on us one-by-one and where will you be? Living alone? Being brave? Is that what you want? Joan pushes past him and heads to the bathroom.
Don’t walk away from me. God damn it, Joanie.
Leave me alone.
No we're going to fucking talk this out.
I can’t do it anymore Joe. I can’t stand the humiliation of holding your coat and arranging your pills and picking the crumbs out of your (MORE)

beard and getting pushed aside with the other wives to talk about god damn shopping trips, while you tell the gathered psychophants that your wife doesn’t write! Your wife who just won the Nobel Prize!
You never told me you were so fucking unhappy.
You should have fucking known. How could you possibly not see it!
So, if I’m such an insensitive and talent-less piece of shit. Why the fuck did you marry me?
Oh God Joe. Again. It’s all about you.
No answer me, I’d like to know. Why did you marry me?
(exhausted by him) I don’t know Joe, I don’t know. I can’t think anymore. I just want to get out of this goddamn gown.
Here. Turn around. Joe unzips the back of her dress for her. Then he starts kissing the back of her neck, expecting that they’re goin have makeup sex.
Joe, no. Joan pushes him away. Joe is too grieved to speak. He bac away and Joan closes the bathroom door on him. Joe stands at the door for a beat, utterly crushed.
Aw fuck it...fuck it.

Joan has shed her gown and is changed into a robe. She’s staring at herself in the mirror, still furious. Then she  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 97. starts throwing her things into her toiletries bag. She opens the door. Joe isn’t there. We FOLLOW Joan back to the bedroom where she goes straigh her suitcase and drops her toiletries in. She avoids look at Joe who’s lying on the bed and starts getting the rest her clothes out of the closet.
Joanie...
What now. Joan turns and sees that Joe is clutching his chest, grimacing. She immediately goes to his side.
Oh my God! Joe nods.
Stay very still. I’m going to call for a medic. Joan grabs the phone and dials up the front desk.
(into phone) This is Mrs. Castleman, I think my husband is having a heart attack. Joan hangs up and sits on the bed with Joe and rubs his chest, trying to soothe him.
Joe you'll be all right...stay with me, keep looking in my eyes... Joe stares at her with a terrified, helpless expression.
Joanie do you love me?
Oh my Darling yes I love you very much. Joe stares at Joan with a look of unspeakable sorrow on h face.
You’re such a good liar, how will I ever know? Joe is leaving her...  54 THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 98.

Don’t leave me Joe... Joe? Don’t leave me. We hear people coming through the front door. The HOTEL MANAGER rushes in with the HOTEL DOCTOR and the HOTEL NURSE, carrying paramedic equipment including defibrillator.
Mrs. Castleman...?!
Mrs. Castleman could you move aside please.
Ambulansen dr pa vag.

The NURSE puts the defibrillator leads on Joe as the Hote Doctor puts the assisted breathing mask on Joe. HOTEL DOCTOR (CONT’D) Vi startar HLR. The NURSE takes out the pads and hands them to the Doctor HOTEL DOCTOR (CONT’D) Everyone stay clear. The Doctor shocks Joe with the defibrillator and his body jumps.

Joan, her eyes puffy with grief, is staring out the windo Is that heaven out there? Will Joe be flying by wearing a pair of wings? David is curled up beside her, dozing.  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 99. We hear the tinkle of ice -- the flight attendant is delivering Joan a scotch. It's the same attendant who we on the plane ride over.
(softly) Here you go, Mrs. Castleman.
Thank you.
I don't know if you remember me, but I served you on the flight coming over. Joan glances at the attendant's breasts which Joe had so admired.
Yes, I remember.
I'm so very sorry for your loss.
Thank you.
You know, I see a lot of couples on my flights, and you and your husband -- I just want to say that I could tell that you had a wonderful relationship.
How?

It was just something about the way you were with each other. I could tell that he so respected you. Another FLIGHT ATTENDANT touches Monica on the shoulder. FLIGHT ATTENDANT MONICA (CONT’D) (to Joan) Excuse me... Monica confers with the other attendant then comes back t Joan. FLIGHT ATTENDANT MONICA (CONT’D) (in a lowered voice) There's someone here who says he knows you -- Nathanial?  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 100.
Oh.
Should I tell him that you're asleep?
No, it's all right. Monica lets Bone in. He comes over to Joan, looking prope solemn. He sees David sleeping and lowers his voice.
Joan. I don't know what to say. I’m just stunned. How are you doing?
We’re still in shock.
We all are. It’s impossible to process.
Nathanial...
Yes? David stirs in his seat. Joan gestures for Bone to get closer. Bone crouches down next to her.
What we were talking about the other day... Bone tries very hard not to look too eager.
Yes...?
I want to say that what you implied isn’t true. And if you malign Joe's talent in any way, I will take you to court. Joan extends her hand.
Good luck, Nathanial. I’m sure it will be a fine book. Bone numbly shakes Joan hand and leaves. Joan touches Dav  THE WIFE FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT (16/12/16) 101.
Did you hear any of that?
Yes.
When we get home, I’m going to sit down with you and your sister and I’m going to tell you everything. David stares at his mother for a beat.

...okay, Ma. David puts his head phones back on, needing to shut down. Joan tucks a blanket around him. Joan reaches into her purse and takes out Joe’s yellow no pad. She stares at Joe’s strong, bold handwriting and his endless list of ideas waiting for Joan to turn them into literary gold. She tears this page off the pad and carefu folds it and gently tucks it in her bag. She stares at th note pad, it’s vast blank page, hers to filled by her alo It’s too much to think about right now, just too much. Overwhelmed, she leans back and shuts her eyes, we hold o her for a beat. Then her eyes pop open. Already a story is starting to fi her head. It’s not over. She’s a writer still.
